posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
Trial N’ Terror is looking into buying a new driver’s station laptop and I was wondering what other teams do as far as ensuring reliability on the hardware level.

I’ve seen the blue tak or hot glue to hold connectors in but I mean more internal to the laptop.

Many laptops today that have dual ports for SSDs seem to support Raid. We could do a RAID 1 to ensure boot volume protection as well as some data retention.

Additionally many laptops today don’t have full size Ethernet ports so we are going to have to get a port replicator. I worry about the reliability of such devices as I use a thunderbolt dock at work and I’ve ran into random issues with it. How do you overcome issues like this?

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked: We opted to get a Framework laptop as our new driver station last year. It is a pricier option, but means that we can replace any part of it that potentially gets damaged in the rough environment at competitions/in the shop. It also means we can reconfigure the ports to whatever layout we require.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Did you get the 13 or the 16? They seem really amazing but I don’t know that I can justify the actual $3k extra for the 16

posts.name: Justin Sommer
posts.cooked: I don’t think that for FRC you need the GPU that is in the 16. You really just need a solid CPU and some RAM

posts.name: MrRoboSteve
posts.cooked:
Driver Station Best Practices — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation (wpilib.org) is the canonical advice on selecting a driver station.  A couple hundred dollar used Lenovo or Dell business grade laptop that runs Windows 11, and meets the other requirements listed in the document, is what you need.

RAID for a SSD in the driver station seems like overkill to me.

link_counts.title: Driver Station Best Practices — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Lenovo ThinkPad T480 Intel i5 8350U 1.70GHz 16GB RAM 256GB SSD 14" Win 11 - B Gr | eBay

posts.cooked:
I agree that RAID seems overkill. Here’s some thoughts we had last year when buying a new one:

We have the budget to afford a laptop that is solely the driver’s station, and we have a few other laptops for shared use. (All of our code team has our own laptops; design is something we’re working on but that’s out of the scope of this.) This means that we can avoid having any extra software running.

We knew we wanted an in-built ethernet port so we could run without a dongle, but (in order to preserve the port since it’s constantly getting plugged in and unplugged, and especially because it’s one of those ports where the bottom is on a lever) we almost always run with a simple male to female cable and leave the adapter plugged in unless there’s an issue (and make sure it’s one that doesn’t just come out - one of the adapters we tried could just be pulled out if you applied upwards pressure).

In a similar vein to wearing out the ethernet, we plug our controllers into a USB hub and leave the hub plugged in constantly.

(Yes, these do make disconnects during a match more likely, but that is not an issue we have had this year or last year, the laptop isn’t actually moving during a match, and I’d rather lose a match because the hub or ethernet adapter came out than have our laptop’s ethernet die and need to quickly buy a replacement which isn’t cheap.)

Don’t get more than you need. Getting a laptop with an inbuilt GPU for example is another thing that can fail. I know these don’t directly answer the question of hardware failures but it’s a few thoughts I had that I wanted to share.
